ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Knowledge of software verification, and the "attitude" of the field.
I learned so much about formal verification and analysis. It was a lot of work but well worth the effort and a lot of fun in the end.
I definitely feel like I got a good survey of the field from this class and gained a much larger awareness and appreciation for all the areas formal methods impacts
The course provides an overview of software verification as a method to ensure that code behaves as expected.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
- I wish Haskell was introduced earlier, or made more explicit in the lecture. Its use in the course projects seems divorced from the class material. That said, I'd like to make clear: I LOVED the Haskell parts, and am very glad that it was covered in this course. Many props to Ben. 

- I feel like the lectures weren't well organized in terms of the contents. Some lectures jump behind and ahead of each other. Even little things like a clear table of contents for the lecture slides would help. (or lecture numbers! Every slide show looks the same, and because they start with 10+ slides of "recap", it's very hard to find what you need when you're reviewing. There _is_ structure, but it might need to be made more explicit)

- The course didn't feel "cumulative" -- largely because it usually isn't made clear beforehand how each new topic fits into the big picture. SAT solvers build on our work with Dafny; this is clear. But how does abstraction checking fit in? After some thinking, you can figure it out -- but if we have a clearer big picture map before, then it helps us when learning something new.

The professor is fantastic and the TA Ben is probably the best TA I have ever had at Yale. The strength is how much information is covered and all the projects are highly relevant, no busy work. The greatest weakness is the lack of structure in the projects, especially with Simplex I would have liked more algorithm guidance especially in the second step. However, the support is there when I ever needed help. Maybe some more detail in the instruction s would be fantastic.
I think the project descriptions could be a bit more detailed/precise to help students get started as well as be confident they have developed a correct solution

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments:
Depends on their goals and background. 
Generally, yes. Especially if Ben is teaching.
I definitely would to an advanced student who is willing to put in the work. Its a very transformative experience and lots of growtgt.
I would recommend the course to people that want to specialise in PL.
